Hi! The fix should be simple. Replace

at::Tensor input1_t = at::native::from_blob(input_vect.data(),{INPUT_SIZE});

with

Tensor input1_t = torch::from_blob(input_vect.data(),{INPUT_SIZE});

Using torch:: instead of at:: for creating a tensor will give you a variable instead of a non-gradient recording tensor.

In general, you should never have to use at::native. If you are including torch/torch.h, you can in fact use torch:: instead of at:: for everything and you won't ever run into any problems. We export everything from at:: into the torch:: namespace. For example:

torch::Tensor x = torch::randn({3, 4});
auto y = torch::relu(x);

Let me know if you have questions or run into any other issues.
body:
Hi! The fix should be simple. Replace
```cpp
at::Tensor input1_t = at::native::from_blob(input_vect.data(),{INPUT_SIZE});
```

with 

```cpp
Tensor input1_t = torch::from_blob(input_vect.data(),{INPUT_SIZE});
```

Using `torch::` instead of `at::` for creating a tensor will give you a variable instead of a non-gradient recording tensor.

In general, you should never have to use `at::native`. If you are including `torch/torch.h`, you can in fact use `torch::` instead of `at::` for everything and you won't ever run into any problems. We export everything from `at::` into the `torch::` namespace. For example:

```cpp
torch::Tensor x = torch::randn({3, 4});
auto y = torch::relu(x);
```

Let me know if you have questions or run into any other issues.
